title: Los Angeles Prices Hit New High Amid Sliding Transactions
text:
Prices reached new highs in the third quarter across Los Angeles’s Downtown and Westside—a swath of the city encompassing high-end neighborhoods such as Bel Air, Brentwood, Pacific Palisades, Beverly Hills and Santa Monica—according to a report Thursday from Douglas Elliman.



The median sales price hit $1.54 million, a 1.6% increase from the same time last year and a record for the city, the brokerage said.

But the rise came amid sliding numbers of transactions, increasing inventory and a typical listing price decrease of 5.6%—the highest discount logged since 2011, said Jonathan Miller, chief executive of appraisal firm Miller Samuel and author of the report.



“It’s the ultimate real estate paradox,” Mr. Miller said. “Sellers are cutting their prices, and the result is a record aggregate price for the period.”



“It just shows you the aspirational pricing phenomenon in luxury real estate,” he said, referring to how much sellers overprice their homes beyond market conditions. “As the seller acclimates [to the market], they have to travel further to meet the buyer.”



It illustrates “how much higher the asking prices were,” he added.



The Los Angeles luxury sector—defined as the top 10% of the market—echoes the overall market, Mr. Miller said. But there is “more strength in the luxury single-family market,” he said.

Median prices for luxury single-family homes rose 8.8% to $9.36 million in the third quarter compared to the same time last year.



Though transactions are is fairly flat, down 2.4%, prices are robust and inventory declined 10%.



Looking ahead, prices are expected to soften across the market.



“Sales trends lead price trends,” Mr. Miller said. “So this is a natural ebb and flow of the market. We expect some downward pressure on prices going forward.”
